zn-body zn--idx-0 zn--ordinary zn-has-multiple-containers zn-has-21-containers" data-eq-pts="xsmall: 0, medium: 460, large: 780, full16x9: 1100" id="body-text" data-vr-zone="zone-1-0" data-zone-label="bodyText" data-containers="21" id="body-text" data-zn-id="body-text"><div class="l-container"><div class="el__leafmedia el__leafmedia--storyhighlights"><div class="el__storyhighlights_wrapper"><div class="el__storyhighlights"><h3 class="el__headline">Story highlights</h3><ul class="el__storyhighlights__list"><li class="el__storyhighlights__item el__storyhighlights--normal">Researchers examined the records of 95,727 children in an 11-year window</li><li class="el__storyhighlights__item el__storyhighlights--normal">"We found that there was no harmful association," says a pediatrician who worked on the study</li><li class="el__storyhighlights__item el__storyhighlights--normal">Researchers also found no increased autism risk from the vaccine for children with older siblings with autism</li></ul></div><div class="ad ad--epic" data-ad-text="show"><div id="ad_ns_btf_01" class="ad-ad_ns_btf_01 ad-refresh-default"></div></div></div></div><div class="el__leafmedia el__leafmedia--sourced-paragraph"><p class="zn-body__paragraph"><cite class="el-editorial-source"> (CNN)</cite>The vaccine for measles, mumps and rubella doesn't bring an increased risk of autism, according to a new study of more than 95,000 children.</p></div><div class="zn-body__paragraph">The study, <a href="http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=2275444" target="_blank">published Tuesday in the Journal of the American Medical Association</a>, is the latest piece of research to <a href="http://www.cnn.com/2014/07/01/health/vaccines-for-kids-safe/">debunk the myth</a> associating the MMR vaccine with autism.</div><div class="ad ad--epic ad--mobile" data-ad-text="show"><div id="ad_rect_atf_02" class="ad-ad_rect_atf_02 ad-refresh-default"></div></div><ul class="cn cn-list-hierarchical-xs cn--idx-4 cn-zoneAdContainer"></ul><div class="zn-body__paragraph"><a href="http://thechart.blogs.cnn.com/2013/03/29/vaccine-autism-connection-debunked-again/">Vaccine-autism connection debunked again</a></div><div class="zn-body__paragraph">Using a claims database from a large commercial health plan, the researchers paid particular attention to children who had older siblings with autism, or ASD, which puts them at a higher genetic risk of developing autism.</div><div class="zn-body__paragraph">"We found that there was no harmful association between the receipt of the MMR vaccine and the development of an autism spectrum disorder," said Anjali Jain, a pediatrician at the Lewin Group, a health care consulting firm in Virginia, who worked on the study.</div><div class="zn-body__read-more"><div class="read-more-gradient"></div><div class="read-more-button"><div class="read-more-link" id="js-body-read-more">Read More</div></div></div><div class="zn-body__read-all"><div class="zn-body__paragraph"><h3>'No evidence' of link</h3></div><div class="zn-body__paragraph">The team of researchers examined the records of 95,727 children in an 11-year window. They studied the risk of developing autism in children who received the MMR vaccine compared with those who didn't.</div><div class="zn-body__paragraph">For children with older siblings diagnosed with autism, the study's authors said they "found no evidence that receipt of either 1 or 2 doses of MMR vaccination was associated with an increased risk of ASD."</div><div class="zn-body__paragraph">The work was funded by the National Institute of Mental Health, National Institutes of Health, and the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services.</div><div class="zn-body__paragraph"><h3>'Beliefs continue to persist'</h3></div><div class="zn-body__paragraph">As dozens of measles cases began popping up in the United States in recent months, <a href="http://www.cnn.com/2015/02/04/us/5-vaccine-myths/">unfounded fears</a> about a link between vaccines and autism resurfaced.</div><div class="zn-body__paragraph">"Although there is a lot of research suggesting that there is no link between the MMR vaccine and autism spectrum disorder, those beliefs continue to persist," said Jain.</div><div class="zn-body__paragraph">The study found that children who had an older sibling with autism were less likely to be vaccinated.</div><div class="zn-body__paragraph">"Their vaccination rates were about 10% less than for kids with unaffected siblings," Jain said.</div><div class="zn-body__paragraph">The recurrent myth about a link between vaccines and autism, propagated by a small but vocal group of anti-vaccine activists, grew out of <a href="http://www.cnn.com/2011/HEALTH/01/05/autism.vaccines/">a now discredited study</a> from 1998 that was published in a British medical journal by a doctor who was later stripped of his license. </div><div class="zn-body__paragraph">"We're not sure as a scientific community what causes autism, but vaccines do not," CNN's Dr. Sanjay Gupta said last month.</div></div><p
